conclusion: Need to find the ratio of q to d for two charged spheres, A and B, on an inclined plane.
Inclined plane with angle θ from the horizontal; sphere A is connected to a wire fixed at the top of the plane.
Wire is parallel to the inclined plane; sphere A has charge +q and mass m.
Sphere B has the same charge +q, placed to the right of sphere A at the same height, separated by distance d.
Both spheres are treated as point charges.
Sphere A is stationary and the tension in the wire is zero.
Other forces acting on sphere A must balance each other since tension in the wire is zero.
Need to analyze forces acting on sphere A to find q/d.
Weight of sphere A is mg, acting vertically downward.
Component of weight along the plane is mg sinθ; component perpendicular to the plane is mg cosθ.
Normal force from the plane equals the perpendicular component of the weight, mg cosθ.
Electrostatic force between sphere A and sphere B is repulsive, given by Coulomb's law: F_electric = k * q^2 / d^2.
Electrostatic force acts along the line connecting the centers of A and B, which is horizontal.
Centers of the two spheres are at the same height and separated by distance d.
Line connecting A and B is horizontal, so electrostatic force is horizontal.
Inclined plane is at an angle θ to the horizontal.
Electrostatic force is perpendicular to the inclined plane.
Horizontal direction is perpendicular to the plane only if θ is 90 degrees.
Need to clarify the direction of the electrostatic force relative to the plane.
Electrostatic force is along the line connecting the centers of A and B, which is horizontal.
Relative to the plane, electrostatic force is perpendicular to the plane.
Horizontal direction is perpendicular to the plane only if θ is 90 degrees.
Confusion about direction of forces due to angle θ.
